images.alt: 'Queen of soul' Aretha Franklin dead at 76
Aretha Franklin performs at the opening of the new Performing Arts Center at Montgomery College in Silver Spring, Maryland, on September 11, 2009.
Aretha Franklin performs at the opening of the new Performing Arts Center at Montgomery College in Silver Spring, Maryland, on September 11, 2009.

info.description: Aretha Franklin, music's "Queen of Soul" who won 18 Grammy awards during a career that spanned six decades, has died at age 76. CNN's Stephanie Elam reports.
info.title: Aretha Franklin Fast Facts

twitter.description: View the Aretha Franklin Fast Facts on CNN and learn more about the life of the "Queen of Soul."
twitter.title: Aretha Franklin Fast Facts

text.markdown:
# Aretha Franklin Fast Facts

CNN Library

Updated 1833 GMT (0233 HKT) September 3, 2018

!['Queen of soul' Aretha Franklin dead at
76](//cdn.cnn.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/140305125035-aretha-franklin-
sitdown-00015307-exlarge-169.jpg)

(CNN)Here's a look at the life of the "Queen of Soul," [Aretha
Franklin](https://www.rockhall.com/inductees/aretha-franklin).

 ** _Personal:_** **  
Birth date:** March 25, 1942

 **Death date:** August 16, 2018

 **Birth place:** Memphis, Tennessee

 **Birth name:** Aretha Louise Franklin

 **Father:** Rev. C. L. (Clarence La Vaughn), minister and gospel singer

**Mother:** Barbara (Siggers) Franklin, gospel singer

**Marriages:** Glynn Turman (April 11, 1978-1984, divorced), Ted White
(1961-1969, divorced)

**Children:** with Ken Cunningham: Kecalf; with Ted White: Theodore; father's
name is not publicly known: Edward and Clarence

 ** _Other Facts:_**  
Had a four-octave vocal range.

Was a self-taught pianist, who learned without knowing how to read music.

Was extremely private, she rarely discussed her personal life or her father's
death.

Her father was shot by burglars in 1979 and remained in a coma until his death
in 1984. [Rev. Jesse Jackson](http://www.cnn.com/2013/02/28/us/jesse-jackson-
fast-facts/index.html) spoke at his funeral.

Claimed reports of her mother abandoning the family in 1948 were not true. The
Franklins separated and the children lived with Rev. Franklin, spending
summers with their mother until Mrs. Franklin died in 1952.

Due to an in-flight turbulence incident in 1982, she had an extreme fear of
flying.

Had 44 [Grammy](http://www.cnn.com/2013/11/14/us/grammy-awards-fast-
facts/index.html) nominations and 18 wins. Franklin also won three special
Grammy awards.

A high school dropout, she had two honorary doctorates of music, from Berklee
College of Music and Yale University.

In addition to receiving a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, she was
inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, the
[NAACP](http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/26/us/naacp-image-awards-fast-
facts/index.html) Image Awards Hall of Fame, and the Apollo Theater Legends
Walk of Fame.

Performed at the inaugural events of three US presidents: [Jimmy
Carter](https://www.cnn.com/2013/01/08/us/jimmy-carter---fast-
facts/index.html), [Bill Clinton](https://www.cnn.com/2013/02/01/us/bill-
clinton-fast-facts/index.html) and [Barack
Obama](https://www.cnn.com/2012/12/26/us/barack-obama---fast-
facts/index.html).

**_Timeline:_** **  
1956 -[](https://www.rockhall.com/inductees/aretha-franklin)**[A gospel album
entitled "Spirituals" is released by a small label called
J.V.B](https://www.rockhall.com/inductees/aretha-franklin). It is Franklin's
first recording. The album is later re-released as "Songs of Faith: The Gospel
Sound of Aretha Franklin."

**1960 -** Signs with Columbia Records.

 **1967 -[](https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7736376
/aretha-franklin-top-40-biggest-billboard-hot-100-hits)**[Her first number one
single, "Respect" is released, along with the
hits](https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7736376/aretha-
franklin-top-40-biggest-billboard-hot-100-hits) "(You Make Me Feel Like) A
Natural Woman" and "Baby I Love You."

 **1968 -** Wins her first two Grammy awards. "Respect" wins the prize for
best rhythm & blues recording and best rhythm & blues solo vocal performance,
female.

**April 9, 1968 -** Sings "Precious Lord, Take My Hand" at the memorial
service of [Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.](http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/17/us
/martin-luther-king-jr-fast-facts/index.html)

 **January 19, 1977 -** [Performs "God Bless America" at the inaugural concert
of President Carter](https://www.nytimes.com/1977/01/20/archives/a-new-spirit-
is-a-national-celebration-of-togetherness-in-tv.html).

 **1982 -** Wins Grammy Award for Best R &B Vocal Performance, Female for
"Hold On I'm Comin'."

 **1986 -** Wins Grammy Award for Best R&B Vocal Performance, Female for
"Freeway Of Love."

 **1987 -** Is the first woman inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

**1988 -** Wins two Grammy Awards for Best R&B Vocal Performance, Female for
"Aretha" and Best R&B Performance by a Duo, with George Michael, "I Knew You
Were Waiting (For Me)."

 **1989 -** Wins Grammy Award for Best Soul Gospel Performance, Female for
"One Lord, One Faith, One Baptism."

 **1991 -** Receives the Grammy Legend Award.

 **January 19, 1993 -** Performs at the inaugural gala of President Clinton.

 **1994 -** Receives the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.

**1997 -** Performs an aria from Puccini's "La Boheme" at the wedding of [Vice
President Al Gore's](http://www.cnn.com/2013/09/02/us/al-gore-fast-
facts/index.html) daughter, Karenna.

 **February 6, 1998 -** Reprises her roll of Mrs. Murphy from "The Blues
Brothers" in the sequel, "The Blues Brothers 2000."

**February 25, 1998 -** Substitutes for an ailing Luciano Pavarotti at the
Grammy Awards performing "Nessun Dorma" by Puccini, unrehearsed.

**September 1999 -** Her autobiography "Aretha: From These Roots," is
published, where she discusses her private and personal life for the first
time.

**September 29, 1999 -** Is presented the National Medal of Arts by the
National Endowment for the Arts.

 **2004 -** Wins Grammy Award for Best Traditional R&B Vocal Performance for
"Wonderful."

 **November 9, 2005 -** Is awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by
[President George W. Bush.](http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/07/us/george-w-bush-
fast-facts/index.html)

 **2006 -** After Franklin points out that no Motown talent was appearing in
the Detroit [Super Bowl ](http://www.cnn.com/2013/09/03/us/super-bowl-fast-
facts/index.html)halftime show, the NFL asks her to sing the national anthem
along with Aaron Neville prior to the game.

 **February 8, 2006 -** Wins Grammy Award for Best Traditional R&B Vocal
Performance for "A House Is Not a Home."

 **February 8, 2008 -** Is Grammy's 2008 MusiCares Person of the Year.

 **February 10, 2008 -** Wins Grammy Award for Best Gospel Performance for
"Never Gonna Break My Faith," shared with Mary J. Blige.

 **February 14, 2008 -** Receives the NAACP Vanguard Award at the annual Image
Awards ceremony.

 **January 20, 2009 -** Performs "My Country 'Tis of Thee" at the inauguration
of President Obama.

**February 2010 -** A Snickers commercial starring Franklin and[ Liza
Minnelli](http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/liza-minnelli-fast-
facts/index.html) airs for the first time.

**July 27, 2010 -** Appears on stage with former [Secretary of State
Condoleezza Rice](http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/08/us/condoleezza-rice-fast-
facts/index.html) on piano, in Philadelphia, to raise money for charity. Rice
is a classical pianist. They perform individually and together, classical, pop
and patriotic selections.

 **August 1, 2010 -** Falls in her home, breaking some ribs. The incident
forces her to [cancel concert
appearances](http://www.cnn.com/2010/SHOWBIZ/Music/08/04/aretha.franklin.injury/)
for August.

 **May 3, 2011 -** Releases new album, "Aretha: A Woman Falling Out of Love."

 **October 8, 2014 ****-** Achieves a milestone in music history by becoming
the first female to earn her 100th hit on Billboard's Hot R &B song chart with
"Rolling in the Deep (The Aretha Version)."

 **October 2014 -** Releases a new album, "Aretha Franklin Sings the Great
Diva Classics."

 **March 2015 -** Performs live on the Motown themed episode of American Idol
in Detroit.

 **September 26, 2015 -** Franklin sings "Amazing Grace" at [the Festival of
Families](https://www.cnn.com/2015/09/26/us/pope-francis-festival-
families/index.html), one of the events sponsored by the
[Vatican](http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/30/world/vatican-fast-facts/index.html)
for [Pope Francis](http://www.cnn.com/2013/03/14/world/pope-francis-fast-
facts/index.html)' visit to Philadelphia.

 **February 7, 2017 -** Franklin announces she will retire from performing in
concert after the release of one more album. "I am retiring this year, she
told a local television station in Detroit. "I will be recording, but this
will be my last year in concert."

 **August 16, 2018 -[](https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/16/entertainment/aretha-
franklin-dead/index.html)**[Dies at her home in
Detroit](https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/16/entertainment/aretha-franklin-
dead/index.html), surrounded by family and friends, according to a statement
on behalf of Franklin's family from her longtime publicist Gwendolyn Quinn.

![In photos: Aretha Franklin](//cdn.cnn.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/180813092457-01
-aretha-franklin-file-restricted-2009-medium-plus-169.jpg)

![Franklin performs at a JVC Jazz Festival concert at New York's Lincoln
Center in 2000.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin sings at civil rights pioneer Rosa Parks' funeral in 2005.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Former President George W. Bush presented Franklin with the Presidential
Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor, in 2005. The medal
is awarded to those who have made contributions to national security, world
peace or culture.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin and Aaron Neville performed the national anthem before the 2006

](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin in 2008.

![Franklin performed "My Country 'Tis of Thee" at the
inauguration of President Barack Obama in 2009.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin at The NAACP Freedom Fund Dinner in 2009.

Rockefeller Center Christmas tree lighting ceremony in
2009.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin during a 2010 concert, accompanied by former Secretary of State

![Franklin and Oprah Winfrey during a star-studded taping of "Surprise
Oprah! A Farewell Spectacular," in Chicago in
2011.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![After canceling six months of public appearances because of medical
problems, Franklin returned to the stage at the Jones Beach Theater in New
York in 2011.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin, seen on screen, at the "American Idol" finale in
2013.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin performs during the National Christmas Tree Lighting ceremony in
Washington, D.C. in
2013.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin waves while standing to receive an honorary Doctor of Arts degree
from Harvard University in
2014.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![An emotional Attorney General Eric Holder, center, and President Barack
Obama react after Franklin finished singing a song for Holder at an event
celebrating the end of his tenure at the Department of Justice in 2015.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Pope Francis looks on as Franklin performs during the 2015 Festival of

](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin performing in 2015 at the National Portrait Gallery, where she was
honored.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin singing at a benefit for the Elton John AIDS Foundation in New York
in 2017.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin and her son Kecalf Cunningham stand under a newly unveiled street
sign named in her honor outside Detroit's Music Hall in
2017.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Aretha Franklin performs at the opening of the new Performing Arts Center at
Montgomery College in Silver Spring, Maryland, on September 11,
2009.](//cdn.cnn.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/180816161000-aretha-franklin-unfurled-
medium-plus-169.jpg)

![After a childhood of singing gospel music in Detroit, where her father was a
minister, Franklin scored her first recording deal at age 18. In 1967 she
signed with Atlantic Records, where she would record a string of
hits.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

1968.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin photographed with Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in the late
1960's. In 1968 she was asked to perform at King's funeral, where she
sang a stirring rendition of "Precious Lord, Take Thy
Hand."](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Aretha Franklin sits for a portrait with her father, Baptist preacher
'CL' \(born Clarence LaVaughn\), and her sister, fellow singer,

![Franklin and Glynn Turman walk down the aisle at their wedding on April 11,
1978.<br /><em><br />Editor's note: A previous version
of this caption identified Franklin's husband as Glynn Russell. His full
name is Glynn Russell
Turman.</em>](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

Brothers."](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

1960's. In 1968 she was asked to perform at King's funeral, where she
sang a stirring rendition of "Precious Lord, Take Thy
Hand."](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Aretha Franklin performs at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on
August 26, 1968.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Aretha Franklin sits for a portrait with her father, Baptist preacher
'CL' \(born Clarence LaVaughn\), and her sister, fellow singer,
Carolyn, in New York in
1971.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Crowds gather for a performance by Franklin at the Apollo Theater in New
York City on June 3, 1971.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin, far left, performs at Jimmy Carter's Presidential Inaugural
Gala on January 20, 1977, in Washington,
D.C.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin and Glynn Turman walk down the aisle at their wedding on April 11,
1978.<br /><em><br />Editor's note: A previous version
of this caption identified Franklin's husband as Glynn Russell. His full
name is Glynn Russell
Turman.</em>](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin on stage in
1980.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Dan Aykroyd \(far left\), John Belushi \(second left\), Aretha Franklin
\(center\) and Matt "Guitar" Murphy \(back right\) in a scene from
the 1980 film, "The Blues
Brothers."](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin and Big Mama Thornton perform together onstage on the television
series, 'Omnibus,' in
1980.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin poses backstage during ChicagoFest in
1981.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin performs "Jumpin' Jack Flash" with Keith Richards and
Ron Wood of the Rolling Stones in
1986.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin sings at the Park West Auditorium in Chicago in
1992.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin preforms at the Lincoln Memorial for President Clinton's
inaugural gala in
1992.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin became the youngest Kennedy Center Honors Awards recipient in
1994.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin performs with, from left, Mariah Carey, Gloria Estefan, Carole King
\(obscured\), Shania Twain and Celine Dion during the "Divas Live - An
Honors Concert for VH1 Save the Music" at New York's Beacon Theater
in
1998.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

![Franklin performs at a JVC Jazz Festival concert at New York's Lincoln
Center in 2000.
](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAJAJEAAAAAAP///////wAAACH5BAEAAAIALAAAAAAQAAkAAAIKlI+py+0Po5yUFQA7)

text.text:
Aretha Franklin Fast Facts
CNN Library
Updated 1833 GMT (0233 HKT) September 3, 2018

(CNN)Here's a look at the life of the "Queen of Soul," Aretha
Franklin.
 Personal: 
Birth date: March 25, 1942
Death date: August 16, 2018
Birth place: Memphis, Tennessee
Birth name: Aretha Louise Franklin
Father: Rev. C. L. (Clarence La Vaughn), minister and gospel singer
Mother: Barbara (Siggers) Franklin, gospel singer
Marriages: Glynn Turman (April 11, 1978-1984, divorced), Ted White
(1961-1969, divorced)
Children: with Ken Cunningham: Kecalf; with Ted White: Theodore; father's
name is not publicly known: Edward and Clarence
 Other Facts:
Had a four-octave vocal range.
Was a self-taught pianist, who learned without knowing how to read music.
Was extremely private, she rarely discussed her personal life or her father's
death.
Her father was shot by burglars in 1979 and remained in a coma until his death
in 1984. Rev. Jesse Jackson spoke at his funeral.
Claimed reports of her mother abandoning the family in 1948 were not true. The
Franklins separated and the children lived with Rev. Franklin, spending
summers with their mother until Mrs. Franklin died in 1952.
Due to an in-flight turbulence incident in 1982, she had an extreme fear of
flying.
Had 44 Grammy nominations and 18 wins. Franklin also won three special
Grammy awards.
A high school dropout, she had two honorary doctorates of music, from Berklee
College of Music and Yale University.
In addition to receiving a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, she was
inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, the
NAACP Image Awards Hall of Fame, and the Apollo Theater Legends
Walk of Fame.
Performed at the inaugural events of three US presidents: Jimmy
Carter, Bill Clinton and Barack
Obama.
Timeline: 
1956 -A gospel album
entitled "Spirituals" is released by a small label called
J.V.B. It is Franklin's
first recording. The album is later re-released as "Songs of Faith: The Gospel
Sound of Aretha Franklin."
1960 - Signs with Columbia Records.
1967 -Her first number one
single, "Respect" is released, along with the
hits "(You Make Me Feel Like) A
Natural Woman" and "Baby I Love You."
1968 - Wins her first two Grammy awards. "Respect" wins the prize for
best rhythm & blues recording and best rhythm & blues solo vocal performance,
female.
April 9, 1968 - Sings "Precious Lord, Take My Hand" at the memorial
service of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
January 19, 1977 - Performs "God Bless America" at the inaugural concert
of President Carter.
1982 - Wins Grammy Award for Best R &B Vocal Performance, Female for
"Hold On I'm Comin'."
1986 - Wins Grammy Award for Best R&B Vocal Performance, Female for
"Freeway Of Love."
1987 - Is the first woman inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
1988 - Wins two Grammy Awards for Best R&B Vocal Performance, Female for
"Aretha" and Best R&B Performance by a Duo, with George Michael, "I Knew You
Were Waiting (For Me)."
1989 - Wins Grammy Award for Best Soul Gospel Performance, Female for
"One Lord, One Faith, One Baptism."
1991 - Receives the Grammy Legend Award.
January 19, 1993 - Performs at the inaugural gala of President Clinton.
1994 - Receives the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.
1997 - Performs an aria from Puccini's "La Boheme" at the wedding of Vice
President Al Gore's daughter, Karenna.
February 6, 1998 - Reprises her roll of Mrs. Murphy from "The Blues
Brothers" in the sequel, "The Blues Brothers 2000."
February 25, 1998 - Substitutes for an ailing Luciano Pavarotti at the
Grammy Awards performing "Nessun Dorma" by Puccini, unrehearsed.
September 1999 - Her autobiography "Aretha: From These Roots," is
published, where she discusses her private and personal life for the first
time.
September 29, 1999 - Is presented the National Medal of Arts by the
National Endowment for the Arts.
2004 - Wins Grammy Award for Best Traditional R&B Vocal Performance for
"Wonderful."
November 9, 2005 - Is awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by
President George W. Bush.
2006 - After Franklin points out that no Motown talent was appearing in
the Detroit Super Bowl halftime show, the NFL asks her to sing the national anthem
along with Aaron Neville prior to the game.
February 8, 2006 - Wins Grammy Award for Best Traditional R&B Vocal
Performance for "A House Is Not a Home."
February 8, 2008 - Is Grammy's 2008 MusiCares Person of the Year.
February 10, 2008 - Wins Grammy Award for Best Gospel Performance for
"Never Gonna Break My Faith," shared with Mary J. Blige.
February 14, 2008 - Receives the NAACP Vanguard Award at the annual Image
Awards ceremony.
January 20, 2009 - Performs "My Country 'Tis of Thee" at the inauguration
of President Obama.
February 2010 - A Snickers commercial starring Franklin and Liza
Minnelli airs for the first time.
July 27, 2010 - Appears on stage with former Secretary of State
Condoleezza Rice on piano, in Philadelphia, to raise money for charity. Rice
is a classical pianist. They perform individually and together, classical, pop
and patriotic selections.
August 1, 2010 - Falls in her home, breaking some ribs. The incident
forces her to cancel concert
appearances
for August.
May 3, 2011 - Releases new album, "Aretha: A Woman Falling Out of Love."
October 8, 2014 - Achieves a milestone in music history by becoming
the first female to earn her 100th hit on Billboard's Hot R &B song chart with
"Rolling in the Deep (The Aretha Version)."
October 2014 - Releases a new album, "Aretha Franklin Sings the Great
Diva Classics."
March 2015 - Performs live on the Motown themed episode of American Idol
in Detroit.
September 26, 2015 - Franklin sings "Amazing Grace" at the Festival of
Families, one of the events sponsored by the
Vatican
for Pope Francis' visit to Philadelphia.
February 7, 2017 - Franklin announces she will retire from performing in
concert after the release of one more album. "I am retiring this year, she
told a local television station in Detroit. "I will be recording, but this
will be my last year in concert."
August 16, 2018 -Dies at her home in
Detroit, surrounded by family and friends, according to a statement
on behalf of Franklin's family from her longtime publicist Gwendolyn Quinn.
